title: Kindergarten: Foundations of Social Studies—Family and Community
subject: Social Studies (2021-)

document.title: 2021 Minnesota K12 Academic Standards in Social Studies Final

1087B0D239F249199A33994832F6616A.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

219D7F6DF0784EA6AC5A744608A077E5.description:
Retell a story about an unfair experience that conveys a power
imbalance (a personal experience or one from a story). Share
what can be learned from this story.

651D8E4A19DD4A32853FC76201CFF584.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

B142B19754DE4C0988457DD63568D414.description:
Create a personal representation of themselves, including their
family and/or ancestors. Discuss the choices made, describing
what is special and important, including strengths and assets.

43802092C8734B21BD9B6E27B60EE663.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

329CB35428B84684A1015241CF457DD5.description:
Retell and discuss a story about diverse individuals or groups in
the past that illustrate honesty, courage, friendship, respect
and/or responsibility.

93966E2D8DA54684BAC8360FBB1BEA14.description:
Connecting Past and Present:
Use historical methods and
sources to identify and analyze
the roots of a contemporary
issue. Design a plan to address it.

9EE489B4743641B98A5ACF043BEB8E32.description:
Use a variety of words to reference time in the past, present
and future. Identify the beginning, middle and end of diverse
historical stories.

DB1C13E3A1D44B65908715CC6C4E88E5.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

1482917B5C4143A192111A8534AEE2F4.description:
Describe how people learn about the past by identifying
different types of historical sources and asking what can be
learned from those sources.

B2808FE9B5984E2A8B97A388F566A4DF.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

2468B95DA8344DCEB4BF23DA16C509C6.description:
Identify how different families and communities celebrate or
commemorate events and engage in respectful conversation
about traditions within an individual’s family/community and
those of other families/communities.

7E922FADF36E497C9E3223F4FE42ACD0.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

C943E5CA7A6A47249CB1D9EC456951DD.description:
Ask historical questions about a past event in an individual’s
family, school or local community.

4C9CA6920A2646A6A8374C5E247ADA0F.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

D7D800232F624A168029DA0D42DEFD95.description:
Create a representation of a favorite place. Explain why it is
important to them and how it makes them feel.

3F1259B5DE93436A9ACB45981E37B659.description:
Culture: Investigate how
sense of place is impacted by
different cultural perspectives.

E457D8FF5C8B4224A53A51BA05222430.description:
Identify physical and human characteristics and find examples
in the local community and within stories.

3E51A78CC80247848C94CBAFDF8EE82B.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

7471B1299BF7481A8E58A2A1275FF1CB.description:
Explain or show routes between locations using both fixed and
dynamic maps from local to global scales.

D5246683BD154C5C8912BCD27D57B2BC.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

56C51DAC615D4EB1AD77506E68223193.description: Explain why people agree to trade.

B7BE9B8AB23A40EFACDACA808451FFD8.description:
Global and International:
Explain why people trade and
why nations encourage or limit
trade. Analyze the costs and
benefits of international trade
and globalization on communities
and the environment.

CF6811E0072A44DB93E46CA25FF2FFDA.description:
Distinguish between goods (objects that can be seen or
touched) and services (actions or activities). Identify goods and
services that could satisfy a specific need or want.

A7F449D8A3CC4859BD6B029AC383661E.description:
Microeconomics: Explain and
evaluate how resources are used
and how goods and services are
distributed within different
economic systems. Analyze how
incentives influence the decisions
of consumers, producers, and
governments. Evaluate the
intended and unintended
consequences of these decisions
from multiple perspectives.

5E5EE3D6F14747DDA92BB301DA70645A.description:
Distinguish between individual needs (conditions necessary to
survive) and individual wants (conditions desired to be happy).

CB5E34880D9141889C2FECBB96120CDC.description:
Personal Finance: Apply
economic concepts and models
to develop individual and
collective financial goals and
strategies for achieving these
goals, taking into consideration
historical and contemporary
conditions that either inhibit or
advance the creation of individual
and generational wealth.

C25E665912A84D56A81D14C1D7FCC4A1.description: Use cost-benefit analysis as a group to solve a problem.

68267AB2176045BE850BE5E6B2B8EEAC.description:
Economic Inquiry: Use
economic models and reasoning
and data analysis to construct an
argument and propose a solution
related to an economic question.
Evaluate the impact of the
proposed solution on various
communities that would be
affected.

F94ED47C89F642BC9514C656D8B2B983.description:
Identify examples of rules in the school and neighborhood
community and explain why they exist. Describe incentives for
following rules and consequences for breaking rules.

09757DEC045B46B08D0E2BB4D0CCC8C9.description:
Governmental Institutions and
Political Processes: Explain and
evaluate processes, rules and
laws of United States
governmental institutions at
local, state and federal levels and
within Tribal Nations.

9C3E8E009E0F4448913C25C9D584039F.description:
List personal group associations and name personal roles and
responsibilities to each of those groups.

6DDE513621BA476C880B35F8A1164D3C.description:
Rights and Responsibilities:
Explain and evaluate rights,
duties and responsibilities in
democratic society.

221FBCCB46324B69AAE81BFF2858D1F0.description:
Consider and describe ways group members show they belong
to the group.

889B9AF29CFD4E2DB20C0BC35954314B.description:
Democratic Values and
Principles: Explain democratic
values and principles that guide
governments, societies and
communities. Analyze the
tensions within the United States
constitutional government.

DBDA15A148E1421B881D5D216BE14014.description:
Demonstrate civic skills in a classroom that reflect an
understanding of civic values by identifying a classroom goal
and listing ways that students work together using civic skills to
address a need or goal.

FB0B832AAF97469C97D4F56FCCBE4AE6.description:
Civic Skills: Apply civic
reasoning and demonstrate civic
skills for the purpose of informed
and engaged lifelong civic
participation.
